content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

As a human player, I would prefer to minimize risk and secure some degree of predictability given my cautious nature. In this game, both choices (R and B) have similar potential for earning 40$ or more in the long run. However, choosing R results in losing money when the other player chooses B, which could potentially happen many times over 75 rounds.

On the other hand, if I consistently pick B, my worst-case scenario is that I get 0$ for each round where the other player picks R (up to 38 rounds), while earning at least 40$ for every round they also pick B. This way, I would still have a positive balance even with a few unfavorable outcomes.

Given these considerations, my choice would be {B} as it offers a more secure and predictable outcome, albeit with lower potential earnings per round compared to R.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

As a human player, since my opponent and I both chose B in the previous round, we earned 40$ each. In this game, there is no specific strategy that guarantees consistent wins or maximum earnings. Given my cautious nature, I will stick with my decision to choose B for the next round as well.
